input: Can I verify my identity for VA benefits online, or do I need to go to a physical location like USPS?
expected_output: Yes, you can verify your identity for VA benefits online. However, if you're unable to upload a photo of your ID or prefer to verify in person, you can do so at a participating USPS location near you. Would you like more information on how to access the online verification process, or do you need assistance finding a USPS location for in-person verification?
context:
URL: https://www.va.gov/resources/can-i-verify-my-identity-in-person-for-my-logingov-account
Title: Can I Verify My Identity In Person For My Login.gov Account? | Veterans Affairs
Content:
Search resources and support Resources and Support All VA.gov Enter a keyword, phrase, or question Can I verify my identity in person for my Login.gov account? Yes. Login.gov offers in-person identity verification at a participating United States Postal Service (USPS) location near you. You can choose this option from the start. Or, you may also have the option to verify your identity in person if you tried to verify online but couldn’t upload a photo of your ID. Learn more about verifying your identity in person on the Login.gov website Tags All Veterans Sign in Good Bad Want to share more feedback? We'll use it to keep improving VA.gov for all Veterans and their families. Complete our 3-question survey. VA benefits Records Apply for a printed Veteran ID card, get your VA benefit letters and medical records, and learn how to apply for a discharge upgrade. Need more help? MyVA411 main information line: 800-698-2411 Last updated: August 9, 2024 Feedback

input: What happens to my access to VA benefits if I delete my Login.gov or ID.me account?
expected_output:
If you delete your Login.gov or ID.me account, you will lose the ability to sign in to VA.gov and other websites using that account. However, deleting your sign-in account will not affect any information in your VA records or your access to VA benefits. You will still be able to access your VA benefits through other means, but you'll need to create a new account if you wish to sign in online again.

If you have any further questions or need assistance with accessing your VA benefits, please let me know!
context:
URL: https://www.va.gov/resources/can-i-delete-my-logingov-or-idme-account
Title: Can I Delete My Login.gov Or ID.me Account? | Veterans Affairs
Content:
Search resources and support Resources and Support All VA.gov Enter a keyword, phrase, or question Can I delete my Login.gov or ID.me account? Yes. You can delete your Login.gov or ID.me account on the account provider’s website. Deleting your sign-in account won’t delete any information in your VA records. You just won’t be able to use that account to sign in to VA.gov or any other websites. input: What steps do I need to take to update my address in my VA profile and ensure that it is reflected in all relevant departments?
expected_output:
To update your address in your VA profile, follow these steps:

1. **Log in to your VA.gov account**: Use your Login.gov or ID.me account to access your profile.
2. **Navigate to your profile settings**: Look for the section relating to your personal information.
3. **Update your address**: Enter your new address in the designated field.

Please note that while you can change your address for certain VA benefits and services through your VA.gov profile, some departments may keep their address records separately. For those departments, you may need to contact them directly to ensure your new address is updated.

If you have more specific questions or need additional assistance, please let me know!

input: How can I reset my Login.gov or ID.me password to access my VA services?
expected_output:
To reset your Login.gov or ID.me password for accessing VA services, you'll need to do so directly through their respective account provider websites, as VA representatives cannot assist with password resets. 

- For Login.gov, please visit the [Login.gov help center](https://www.login.gov/help) for guidance.
- For ID.me, you can find assistance in the [ID.me support section](https://help.id.me).

If you need further assistance with VA services or have any other questions, please let me know!
context:

Content:
Search resources and support Resources and Support All VA.gov Enter a keyword, phrase, or question Can I call VA to reset my Login.gov or ID.me password? No. Our VA contact center representatives can’t reset your Login.gov or ID.me password for you. This includes representatives at our My HealtheVet help desk. You can get help with resetting your Login.gov or ID.me password directly from the account provider websites. input: What are the differences between using Login.gov and ID.me for creating an account to access my VA benefits?
expected_output:
Using Login.gov and ID.me to create an account for accessing your VA benefits involves similar steps but some key differences. 

1. **Account Creation Requirements**:
   - **Login.gov**: Requires an email address and a password with at least 12 characters.
   - **ID.me**: Requires an email address and a password with at least 8 characters, which must include at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter, and one number.

2. **Authentication**:
   - Both systems require you to set up multifactor authentication for added security.

3. **Identity Verification**:
   - Both platforms require you to verify your identity, typically using a government-issued ID and your Social Security number. 

4. **Usage**:
   - Both accounts can be used to access VA benefits and other government services, allowing for a unified login across various platforms.

If you need further details on how to choose between the two or specifics on the verification process, please let me know!
context: acidad. Lea la política de privacidad en el sitio web de ID.me (en inglés) Tanto Login.gov como ID.me cumplen las normas de seguridad modernas. Ambas cuentas protegen sus datos para que solo usted pueda acceder y cambiar su información almacenada. Tanto Login.gov como ID.me le permiten usar una cuenta única y segura para acceder a sus beneficios y servicios de VA. Puede utilizar cualquiera de las cuentas para administrar otros beneficios y servicios gubernamentales (como los beneficios del seguro social). Creación de su cuenta ¿Cómo creo una cuenta de Login.gov? Puede crear su cuenta en el sitio web de Login.gov . Esto es lo que necesitará: Una dirección de correo electrónico Una contraseña única que incluya al menos 12 caracteres Aprenda a crear una cuenta de Login.gov para VA (en inglés) Cuando configure su cuenta, deberá configurar la autenticación multifactor. Obtenga más información sobre la autenticación multifactor Obtenga información sobre los métodos de autenticación multifactor en el sitio web de Login.gov La primera vez que utilice su cuenta para administrar sus beneficios o información de VA, deberá verificar su identidad. Esto es lo que necesitará: Su licencia de conducir u otra identificación expedida por el estado y Su número de seguro social y Un número de teléfono de los EE. UU. Nota: Si no tiene un número de teléfono de los EE. UU., Login.gov podrá enviarle una carta a su dirección postal. Obtenga más información sobre cómo verificar su identidad en el sitio web de Login.gov ¿Qué significa verificar mi identidad y por qué tengo que hacerlo? La verificación de su identidad es un proceso único que le pedimos que complete para su cuenta de Login.gov o ID.me . El proceso suele tomar unos 10 minutos. Durante este proceso, el proveedor de la cuenta ( Login.gov o ID.me ) le pedirá que proporcione cierta información personal y su identificación (ID, por sus siglas en inglés). Este proceso nos ayuda a garantizar que la persona que crea su cuenta sea realmente usted y no alguien que finja ser usted. Es muy parecido al proceso de la apertura de una cuenta bancaria. La verificación de su identidad no tiene nada que ver con que confiemos o no en que usted es quien dice ser. Se trata de protegerlo de los estafadores que puedan intentar configurar una cuenta a su nombre para acceder a su información y beneficios. Después de verificar su identidad, no tendrá que volver a hacerlo para esa cuenta a menos que pierda el acceso al método de autenticación multifactor de su cuenta o necesite volver a crearla. En el futuro, es posible que le pidamos que nos ayude a volver a verificar su identidad una vez cada varios años para su mayor protección. ¿Cómo creo una cuenta de ID.me? Puede crear su cuenta en el sitio web de ID.me . Esto es lo que necesitará: Una dirección de correo electrónico Una contraseña única que incluya al menos 8 caracteres (y al menos 1 letra mayúscula, 1 letra minúscula y 1 número) Cuando cree su cuenta, deberá configurar la autenticación multifactor.

input: What do I need to do to qualify for a DS Logon account to access my VA benefits and services?
expected_output:
To qualify for a DS Logon account, you need to meet one of the following criteria:

1. You are a Veteran or service member.
2. You are the spouse or adult dependent of a Veteran or service member.
3. You are a surrogate for a Veteran and have legal authority to make medical decisions for them.

If you meet any of these qualifications, you can create a DS Logon account to access DOD websites and VA services. For further information on creating your DS Logon account, please visit the DS Logon website. 

If you have more specific questions about the process or need further assistance, feel free to ask!
context:
URL: https://www.va.gov/resources/ds-logon-faqs
Title: DS Logon FAQs | Veterans Affairs
Content:
Search resources and support Resources and Support All VA.gov Enter a keyword, phrase, or question DS Logon FAQs You can sign in to Defense Department (DOD) websites with a DS Logon account. Keep reading on this page to learn more about DS Logon . What’s Premium DS Logon? Premium DS Logon is a secure account that Veterans and service members can use to sign in to DOD websites, like TRICARE and milConnect. You can also use your DS Logon username and password to sign in to VA.gov and other VA websites through September 30, 2025 . After this date, you'll need to use either a Login.gov or ID.me account to sign in to VA.gov and other VA online services. This change won't affect your ability to use your DS Logon username and password for DOD website. Learn about creating a Login.gov or ID.me account for VA Can I get a DS Logon account? You can get a DS Logon account to sign in to DOD websites if one of these describes you: You’re a Veteran or service member You’re the spouse or adult dependent of a Veteran or service member You’re the surrogate for a Veteran (you have legal authority to make medical decisions for a Veteran) You can learn more about creating DS Logon accounts on the DS Logon website. Learn more on the DS Logon website Will my DS Logon account or password expire? Your DS Logon account will never expire. But you’ll need to create a new password every 60 days. This helps keep your account secure. Create a new password on the DS Logon website Tags All Veterans Sign in Good Bad Want to share more feedback? We'll use it to keep improving VA.gov for all Veterans and their families. Complete our 3-question survey. Related information VA benefits Health care Apply for VA health care, find out how to access services, and manage your health and benefits online. Need more help? MyVA411 main information line: 800-698-2411 Last updated: July 11, 2023 Feedback

input: What are the steps I need to take to set up direct deposit for my VA benefits, and what specific bank account information do I need to provide?
expected_output:
To set up direct deposit for your VA benefits, you can follow these steps:

1. **Online Setup**: 
   - Sign into your VA.gov profile.
   - Navigate to the section for managing your direct deposit information.
   - Follow the step-by-step instructions provided online.

2. **By Phone**: 
   - Call the VA at 800-827-1000 (TTY: 711) during business hours (Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. ET).

3. **In Person**: 
   - Visit your nearest VA regional office for assistance.

4. **Using Form**: 
   - If you don’t have internet access, you can fill out the Direct Deposit Sign-Up Form (VA Form SF-1199a) to update your information. 

Regarding your bank account information, you will typically need to provide:
- Your bank's name.
- Your account number.
- The bank's routing number.

If you don’t have a bank account, the Veterans Benefits Banking Program (VBBP) can connect you with a bank that will help you set one up. Would you like more information on the VBBP or help with anything else?
context:
URL: https://www.va.gov/resources/direct-deposit-for-your-va-benefit-payments
Title: Direct Deposit For Your VA Benefit Payments | Veterans Affairs
Content:
Search resources and support Resources and Support All VA.gov Enter a keyword, phrase, or question Direct deposit for your VA benefit payments Learn about getting your VA benefit payments through direct deposit. If you don’t already have a bank account, the Veterans Benefits Banking Program (VBBP) can connect you with a bank that will work with you to set up an account. If you already have one, find out how to change your direct deposit information. What’s direct deposit? When you sign up for direct deposit, we transfer money electronically to your bank account on the day you get paid. You can choose to get your VA pension payments, disability compensation, and education payments through direct deposit. If you switch from getting paper checks to receiving your payment through direct deposit, you’ll get your payments faster because you won’t be waiting for your check to arrive by mail. You’ll also have access to the funds in your account right away. How do I add or change VA benefit direct deposit information online? You can add or change your direct deposit information for VA disability compensation, pension benefits, or education benefits online. You’ll manage this information in your VA.gov profile. Get step-by-step instructions for changing your direct deposit information online How do I set up direct deposit for VA benefits by phone or in person? Here’s how to set up direct deposit by phone: Call us at 800-827-1000 ( TTY: 711 ). We’re here Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. ET. For international direct deposit updates, call us at 918-781-7550 . We’re here Monday through Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. ET. To set up direct deposit in person, go to your nearest VA regional office. Find your nearest VA regional office Note: If you don’t have access to the internet or a phone, you can update your direct deposit information with the Direct Deposit Sign-Up Form (VA Form SF-1199a). Get VA Form SF-1199a to download Can I set up direct deposit for health care travel reimbursement? Yes. You must set up direct deposit to receive your reimbursement payments. Get instructions for how to set up direct deposit for travel pay reimbursement What if I don’t have a bank account, but I want to use direct deposit? The Veterans Benefits Banking Program (VBBP) provides a list of Veteran-friendly banks and credit unions that will work with you to set up an account, or help you qualify for an account, so you can use direct deposit. To get started, call one of the participating banks or credit unions listed on the VBBP website. Be sure to mention the Veterans Benefits Banking Program. Go to the VBBP website for more information Tags All Veterans Payments and debt Good Bad Want to share more feedback? We'll use it to keep improving VA.gov for all Veterans and their families. Complete our 3-question survey. Related information VA benefits Disability File a claim for disability compensation for conditions related to your military service, and manage your benefits over time. Pension Apply for monthly payments for wartime Veterans and survivors with limited or no income who meet certain age and disability requirements. Education and training Apply for and manage your GI Bill and other education benefits to help pay for college and cover expenses while you’re training for a job. Need more help? MyVA411 main information line: 800-698-2411 Last updated: July 24, 2024 Feedback

input: What steps should I follow to obtain my VA benefit letters and medical records?
expected_output:
To obtain your VA benefit letters and medical records, follow these steps:

1. **Access VA Benefit Letters:** You can retrieve your benefit letters through your VA account on the VA website. If you don’t have an account, you may need to create one.

2. **Request Medical Records:** To get your medical records, you can submit a request through the VA’s health information management system. You can also call your local VA facility for assistance.

If you need further assistance or have specific questions, consider reaching out to the MyVA411 main information line at 800-698-2411. Is there anything else I can help you with?
context: get your VA benefit letters and medical records, and learn how to apply for a discharge upgrade. Need more help? MyVA411 main information line: 800-698-2411 Last updated: June 9, 2025 Feedback

input: I need help understanding how to create an account on VA.gov. Should I use Login.gov or ID.me, and what are the steps I need to follow?
expected_output:
To create an account on VA.gov, you will need to choose between Login.gov and ID.me. Both options allow you to manage your VA benefits and services online. Here’s a brief overview of each:

- **Login.gov**: This is a government-managed account that provides access to VA and other government services.
- **ID.me**: This is a non-governmental account provider that works with various organizations, including the VA.

### Steps to Create Your Account:

1. **Visit the VA website**: Go to [VA.gov](https://www.va.gov/resources/creating-an-account-for-vagov-esp).
2. **Choose Your Account**: Decide whether you want to use Login.gov or ID.me.
3. **Follow Instructions**: 
   - For **Login.gov**, follow the instructions provided on the site to set up your account.
   - For **ID.me**, similarly, follow the dedicated steps outlined.

These accounts let you access various services such as checking your claim status, updating personal information, managing healthcare appointments, and more.

If you have specific questions about the process or how to prepare for these changes coming in 2025, feel free to ask!
context:
URL: https://www.va.gov/resources/creating-an-account-for-vagov-esp
Title: Creación De Una Cuenta Para VA.gov | Veterans Affairs
Content:
English | Español Search resources and support Resources and Support All VA.gov Enter a keyword, phrase, or question Creación de una cuenta para VA.gov A partir de 2025, deberá utilizar una cuenta de Login.gov o ID.me para iniciar sesión en todos los sitios web y aplicaciones de VA, incluidos VA.gov, el sitio web My HealtheVet y la aplicación móvil de VA: Health and Benefits (VA: Salud y Beneficios). Siga leyendo para obtener más información sobre cómo crear una cuenta gratuita de Login.gov o ID.me para administrar en línea sus beneficios, servicios e información de VA. Instrucciones paso a paso Le guiaremos en cada etapa del proceso para crear su cuenta de Login.gov o ID.me para VA. Cómo crear una cuenta de Login.gov para VA (en inglés) Cómo crear una cuenta de ID.me para VA (en inglés) Si desea obtener más información sobre cómo elegir entre una cuenta de Login.gov o ID.me , o si tiene preguntas sobre la creación de su cuenta o cómo prepararse para los cambios de inicio de sesión de su cuenta de VA a partir de 2025, siga leyendo. Cómo elegir su cuenta ¿Por qué debería crear una cuenta para iniciar sesión en VA.gov? Cuando crea una cuenta de Login.gov o ID.me , puede acceder en línea a sus beneficios, cuidado de la salud e información de VA, y administrarlos. Puede utilizar su cuenta para iniciar una sesión en VA.gov, en aplicaciones móviles de VA y en todo otro servicio en línea de VA. Estas son algunas cosas que puede hacer con una cuenta: Solicitar beneficios Verificar el estado de su reclamación Actualizar su dirección y demás información de contacto en varios beneficios y servicios de VA Verificar el estado de sobrepagos por beneficios o facturas de copagos que pueda tener y solicitar ayuda con estos También puede hacer estas cosas para velar por su salud: Renovar sus recetas Comunicarse de manera privada y segura con su equipo de cuidado de la salud Solicitar o programar algunas citas de salud Revisar los resultados de exámenes y de pruebas de laboratorio También puede usar su cuenta para iniciar sesiones en otros sitios web gubernamentales para administrar sus beneficios, como los beneficios del seguro social. ¿Qué tipo de cuenta debería crear para administrar mis beneficios de VA en línea? Puede crear una cuenta de Login.gov o ID.me . Lo que debe saber: Login.gov es el proveedor de cuenta única de nuestro gobierno para VA y otros beneficios y servicios que ofrece el gobierno. La Administración General de Servicios de los EE. UU. crea y mantiene su cuenta. Para informarse sobre la manera en que nuestro gobierno protege su información, lea la política de privacidad. Lea la política de privacidad en el sitio web de Login.gov ID.me es un proveedor de cuentas no gubernamental que tiene contratos con organizaciones gubernamentales y no gubernamentales. ID.me crea y mantiene su cuenta. Para informarse sobre la manera en que ID.me protege su información, lea la política de priv

input: ¿Cómo puede un veterano anciano encontrar rápidamente un centro de atención médica del VA cercano en caso de una emergencia?
expected_output:
Para que un veterano anciano encuentre rápidamente un centro de atención médica del VA cercano en caso de una emergencia, se recomienda visitar el sitio web de VA donde puede localizar centros de salud y hospitales en su área. También puede llamar a la línea de información MyVA411 al 800-698-2411 para obtener asistencia directa y orientación sobre su ubicación específica.

¿Necesita ayuda con algo más o información adicional sobre beneficios específicos del VA?
context: oficina regional, cementerio u otra instalación local de VA. Encuentre un centro de VA cerca de usted (en inglés) ¿Tendré que incorporar la autenticación multifactor debido a este cambio? Sí. Tanto Login.gov como ID.me requieren que se implemente la autenticación multifactor (MFA, por sus siglas en inglés) como parte del proceso de configuración de una cuenta. Esta capa adicional de protección nos ayuda a garantizar que es usted quien intenta utilizar su cuenta de inicio de sesión y no alguien que se hace pasar por usted. La autenticación multifactor es una práctica común en muchos sitios web y aplicaciones. Es posible que ya la utilice para acceder a su correo electrónico, cuenta bancaria o cuentas de redes sociales. Cuando configure su cuenta de Login.gov o ID.me , podrá elegir la opción de autenticación multifactor que mejor se amolde a sus necesidades. Visite la guía de opciones para la autenticación multifactor de Login.gov Visite la guía de opciones para la autenticación multifactor de ID.me Tags All Veterans Sign in Good Bad Want to share more feedback? We'll use it to keep improving VA.gov for all Veterans and their families. Complete our 3-question survey. Related information VA benefits Records Apply for a printed Veteran ID card, get your VA benefit letters and medical records, and learn how to apply for a discharge upgrade. Need more help? MyVA411 main information line: 800-698-2411 Last updated: January 31, 2025 Feedback

input: What are the steps to link my VA profile with a third-party application for better access to my benefits?
expected_output:
To link your VA profile with a third-party application for better access to your benefits, follow these steps:

1. **Sign In**: When the third-party app or website prompts you to connect, sign in using a verified account through one of our account providers (like Login.gov or ID.me). If you don’t have a verified account, you can create one for free.

2. **Review Permissions**: Check the information the app is asking to access from your VA profile. Make sure you are comfortable with sharing that information.

3. **Allow Access**: If you’re satisfied with the permissions, allow the app to access your data.

If you encounter any issues during this process, please contact the app’s customer support for assistance. If you have any further questions or need more details, feel free to ask!
context:
URL: https://www.va.gov/resources/connected-apps-faqs
Title: Connected Apps FAQs | Veterans Affairs
Content:
Search resources and support Resources and Support All VA.gov Enter a keyword, phrase, or question Connected apps FAQs Get answers to common questions about third-party connected websites and applications. These apps aren’t created by VA, but you can connect them to your profile and they’ll have access to your personal VA data, like your health or service records. Using connected apps Connected apps are third-party (non-VA) applications or websites that can share certain information from your VA.gov profile. They can only access this information after you give us your permission to share it. When you connect to an app, you can use the app's services without having to manually enter your shared information. For example, you can link information from your VA health records to an app that helps you track your health. We offer this feature for your convenience. It’s always your choice whether to connect, or stay connected, to a third-party app. We designed and manage My HealtheVet and VA Mobile apps specifically for the Veterans, service members, and caregivers we serve. Manage your health care with My HealtheVet Find VA Mobile apps Connected apps are designed by organizations outside of VA. These apps can receive only certain personal information, like your VA health or service records, that you tell us to share with them. You can find third-party apps for Veterans in our app directory. Check back often to connect to new apps. Find apps you can use Take these steps to connect the app: When the app (or website) prompts you to connect your VA data, sign in with a verified account through one of our account providers. If you don’t already have a verified account, you can create a free Login.gov or ID.me account now. Learn about creating an account for VA.gov Review the information the app is asking to access. If you’re comfortable sharing that information, allow access. If you have trouble connecting the app, contact the app’s support for help. Find apps you can use Yes. If you no longer want to share your information with an app, you can disconnect it from your VA.gov profile at any time. The app will then no longer have access to new profile information. To disconnect from an app: 1. Sign in to VA.gov 2. Select your name, then Profile . 3. Within your profile, select Connected apps . 4. Find the site or app, and select Disconnect . Note: Some apps may still store information you’ve already shared. If you’d like to ask the app to delete any stored information, contact the app’s support. If you’re concerned that the app may have misused your information, email us at api@va.gov . This depends on the third-party app you want to use. Connected apps are available for all modern device types, like desktop computers, tablets, iPhones, and Android phones. Some of these third-party apps work only with certain devices or operating systems. But more options will become available as more developers design apps for Veterans. Privacy and security with connected apps No. You don't need to connect your VA.gov profile to any third-party apps. We offer this option for your convenience only. In some cases, you can manually enter your information instead. A connected app can only access the information and permissions you see listed when you authorize the connection. This list will vary for each app. It depends on the app’s policy. Once you’ve disconnected an app, they'll no longer receive new information about you from VA. However, you may still need to request that they permanently delete data they’ve already collected. Refer to your app’s privacy policy or contact their customer support if you have specific questions. Take these 3 steps to protect your information: Disconnect from the app. Contact the app’s support and ask them to permanently delete any stored information they may still have from you. Email us at api@va.gov to report the app. Support with connected apps If you’re having trouble connecting to an app, contact the app’s customer support for help. This depends on the problem: If your health records are missing: It can take up to 36 hours for new health records to appear. This gives your health care provider time to discuss results with you before making them available online. If it’s been more than 3 days since your last appointment, or if you need your information sooner, contact your VA health care team. If your information isn’t accurate: Call our MyVA411 main information line at 800-698-2411 ( TTY: 711 ). Or visit a VA health facility near you and ask a staff member for help. Find a

input: What are the options for verifying my identity for VA benefits if I don't have access to a mobile phone?
expected_output:
If you don’t have access to a mobile phone, you still have options to verify your identity for VA benefits. Here are the methods you can use:

1. **For Login.gov**: 
   - You can verify your identity at a participating U.S. post office. 
   - If you don’t have a U.S. phone number, you can verify your address by mail.

2. **For ID.me**:
   - You can verify your identity through a video call using a computer with a webcam and an internet connection. You'll need to upload photos of your ID during the call.
   - Alternatively, you can schedule an in-person appointment at a participating location of The UPS Store.

For multifactor authentication (MFA), both services allow methods that do not require a mobile phone, such as using a security key, a landline phone, or backup codes.

If you need more specifics on the verification processes or assistance, feel free to ask!
context:
URL: https://www.va.gov/resources/can-i-get-a-logingov-or-idme-account-if-i-dont-have-a-mobile-phone
Title: Can I Get A Login.gov Or ID.me Account If I Don’t Have A Mobile Phone? | Veterans Affairs
Content:
Search resources and support Resources and Support All VA.gov Enter a keyword, phrase, or question Can I get a Login.gov or ID.me account if I don’t have a mobile phone? Yes. But you’ll need to use alternate methods to verify your identity and add multifactor authentication (MFA). For Login.gov: You can verify your identity at a participating U.S. post office. If you don’t have a U.S. phone number at all, you may be able to verify your address by mail. Learn about verifying in person (Login.gov website) Learn about verifying by mail (Login.gov website) For ID.me: You can verify your identity on a video call. You’ll need a computer with a webcam and internet connection. And you’ll need to upload photos of your ID from the computer. Or you can book an appointment to verify your identity in person at a participating location of The UPS Store. Learn about verifying on a video call (ID.me website) Learn about in-person verification appointments (ID.me website) For both accounts: You can choose an MFA method that doesn’t require a mobile phone, like a security key, landline, or backup codes. Review MFA methods (Login.gov website) Review MFA methods (ID.me website) Tags All Veterans Sign in Good Bad Want to share more feedback? We'll use it to keep improving VA.gov for all Veterans and their families. Complete our 3-question survey. Related information VA benefits Records Apply for a printed Veteran ID card, get your VA benefit letters and medical records, and learn how to apply for a discharge upgrade. Need more help? MyVA411 main information line: 800-698-2411 Last updated: June 4, 2025 Feedback

input: What are the steps I need to follow to verify my identity for my VA account?
expected_output:
To verify your identity for your VA account, follow these steps:

1. **Choose an Account Provider**: You can use either Login.gov or ID.me to create your account.

2. **Gather Required Information**:
   - An email address
   - A unique password (at least 8 characters, with 1 uppercase letter, 1 lowercase letter, and 1 number)
   - An accepted form of ID (U.S. driver’s license, state-issued ID, passport, or passport card)

3. **Complete the Verification Process**: 
   - For **ID.me**: You can verify online, via a video call, or in person at participating locations (like The UPS Store).
   - For **Login.gov**: You can verify in person at a U.S. post office or by mail if you don't have a U.S. phone number.

4. **Set Up Multifactor Authentication (MFA)**: Choose an MFA method for added security, such as an authenticator app, security key, or landline.

5. **Follow the Step-by-Step Instructions**: 
   - Get detailed instructions for ID.me [here](ID.me website).
   - Get detailed instructions for Login.gov [here](Login.gov website).

If you need further assistance or have specific questions about your verification process, please let me know!
context: to verify your identity for your Login.gov account Learn more about verifying your identity for VA Identity verification is a one-time process that we ask you to complete for your Login.gov or ID.me account. The process often takes about 10 minutes. During this process, the account provider ( Login.gov or ID.me ) will ask you to provide certain personal information and identification (ID). This process helps us make sure that the person creating your account is really you—and not someone pretending to be you. It’s a lot like the process for setting up a bank account. Identity verification is not about whether we trust that you’re who you say you are. It’s about protecting you from scammers who may try to set up an account in your name to access your information and benefits. After you verify your identity, you won’t have to do it again for that account unless you lose access to your account’s multifactor authentication method or need to recreate your account. In the future, we may ask you to help us reverify your identity once every several years for added protection. Here’s what you’ll need to get started: An email address A unique password that includes at least 8 characters (with at least 1 uppercase letter, 1 lowercase letter, and 1 number) A way to add an extra layer of protection to your account (called multifactor authentication or MFA), like an authenticator app or mobile phone to get text message codes Get step-by-step instructions to create your ID.me account Learn about MFA methods on the ID.me website The first time you use your account to manage your VA benefits or information, you’ll need to verify your identity. This one-time process helps us protect all Veterans’ information and prevent scammers from stealing your VA benefits. You’ll need a U.S. driver’s license, state-issued ID, passport, passport card, or other accepted ID documents. You may be able to verify online or in person at a participating location of The UPS Store. Get step-by-step instructions to verify your identity with ID.me Learn more about verifying your identity for VA Yes. But you’ll need to use alternate methods to verify your identity and add multifactor authentication (MFA). For Login.gov: You can verify your identity at a participating U.S. post office. If you don’t have a U.S. phone number at all, you may be able to verify your address by mail. Learn about verifying in person (Login.gov website) Learn about verifying by mail (Login.gov website) For ID.me: You can verify your identity on a video call. You’ll need a computer with a webcam and internet connection. And you’ll need to upload photos of your ID from the computer. Or you can book an appointment to verify your identity in person at a participating location of The UPS Store. Learn about verifying on a video call (ID.me website) Learn about in-person verification appointments (ID.me website) For both accounts: You can choose an MFA method that doesn’t require a mobile phone, like a security key, landline, or backup codes. Review MFA methods (Login.gov website) Review MFA methods (ID.me website) We can help guide you to fix some common issues as you create your account and verify your identity. Get support for common Login.gov and ID.me issues Or you can get more help on each account provider’s website. Go to the Login.gov help center Go to the ID.me support section Identity verification and multifactor authentication work together to protect your identity and personal information: Identity verification is a one-time process. You complete this process when you first set up your sign-in account. To verify your identity, you provide certain personal information and identification (ID). Identity verification helps us make sure only you can create your sign-in account—and no scammer can create one in your name. Multifactor authentication (MFA) is an extra layer of protection that’s part of the process of signing in to use your account. When you first set up your account, you set up your choice of MFA method (like an authenticator app) on a device only you have access to. Then, you use that method to provide a specific code we send you each time you sign in. Multifactor authentication helps us make sure only you can use your sign-in account to access and manage your benefits and health care. Preparing for VA sign-in changes We’re moving to a simpler, more modern, sign-in experience in 2025, with 2 secure sign-in account options ( Login.gov and ID.me ). Here’s what will change for Veterans and beneficiaries like you: As of March 5, 2025 , you can no longer

input: What are the steps to create a Login.gov or ID.me account to manage my VA benefits?
expected_output:
To create a Login.gov or ID.me account for managing your VA benefits, follow these steps:

1. **Choose Your Account Type**:
   - **Login.gov**: Ideal if you have a Social Security number and a valid state-issued ID.
   - **ID.me**: Choose this if you live outside the U.S., don’t have a Social Security number, or have specific state ID issues.

2. **Visit the VA.gov Sign-in Page**: Go to the VA.gov sign-in page.

3. **Create an Account**: Select "Create an account with Login.gov" or "Create an account with ID.me."

4. **Provide Required Information**:
   - A unique personal email address.
   - A password with at least 12 characters.
   - Set up multifactor authentication (MFA), such as using an authenticator app or a mobile phone for text codes.

5. **Verify Your Identity**: The first time you use the account, you'll need to verify your identity using a valid, unexpired driver’s license or state ID.

If you need step-by-step instructions or further information on account creation, please visit the resource link [Creating An Account For VA.gov](https://www.va.gov/resources/creating-an-account-for-vagov). Do you have specific issues or details that you need assistance with regarding the account setup?
context:
URL: https://www.va.gov/resources/creating-an-account-for-vagov
Title: Creating An Account For VA.gov | Veterans Affairs
Content:
English | Español Search resources and support Resources and Support All VA.gov Enter a keyword, phrase, or question Creating an account for VA.gov Starting in 2025, you’ll need to use a Login.gov or ID.me account to sign in to all VA websites and apps—including VA.gov, the My HealtheVet website, and the VA: Health and Benefits mobile app. Keep reading to learn about creating a free Login.gov or ID.me account to manage your VA benefits, services, and information online. Get step-by-step instructions We’ll guide you through each step of creating your Login.gov or ID.me account for VA online. For a Login.gov account Get step-by-step instructions to create a Login.gov account for VA Play a video on how to create a Login.gov account for VA (YouTube) For an ID.me account Get step-by-step instructions to create an ID.me account for VA Play a video on how to create an ID.me account for VA (YouTube) If you want to learn more about choosing between a Login.gov or ID.me account, or if you have questions about creating your account or preparing for VA’s sign-in changes in 2025, keep reading. Choosing your account When you create a Login.gov or ID.me account, you can access and manage your VA benefits, health care, and information online. You can use your account to sign in to VA.gov, VA mobile apps, and any other VA online service. Here are some things you can do with an account: Apply for benefits Check your claim status Update your address and other contact information across several VA benefits and services Check the status of and request help with any benefit overpayments or copay bills you may have You can also do these things to manage your health: Refill prescriptions Communicate privately and securely with your health care team Request or schedule some health appointments Review lab and test results You can also use your account to sign in to some other government websites to manage benefits like Social Security benefits. Here’s what to know: Login.gov is our government’s one account provider. The U.S. government creates and maintains your account. Read Login.gov's privacy policy on their website ID.me is a non-government account provider that contracts with government and non-government organizations. ID.me creates and maintains your account. Read ID.me's privacy policy on their website Both accounts meet the latest federal security standards. And both accounts offer you access to manage your VA benefits and care—and other government benefits—online. If any of these descriptions are true for you, you’ll need to choose ID.me : You live outside the U.S. You don’t have a Social Security number You don’t have a current driver’s license or other state-issued ID Your phone is on a plan that’s not in your name and you want to verify your identity online You have a non-driver’s-license state ID from Alaska, Delaware, Nevada, or Wisconsin Note: If the address listed on your ID is a PO Box, we recommend choosing ID.me . Many people create accounts that they forget they have over time. The best way to find out if you already have a Login.gov or ID.me account is to try to create a new one. To create a new account, go to our VA.gov sign-in page. Then select Create an account with Login.gov or Create an account with ID.me . If you try to create an account and you already have one, the sign-in service provider will tell you. You can then try to reset your email. Go to our VA.gov sign-in page Creating your account You can create your account for VA online. Here’s what you’ll need: A unique personal email address  that only you use A unique password that includes at least 12 characters A way to add an extra layer of protection to your account (called multifactor authentication or MFA), like an authenticator app or mobile phone to get text message codes Get step-by-step instructions to create a Login.gov account for VA Learn about MFA methods on the Login.gov website The first time you use your account to manage your VA benefits or information, you’ll need to verify your identity. This one-time process helps us protect all Veterans’ identities and prevent scammers from stealing your VA benefits. You must have a valid, unexpired driver’s license or state ID. You may be able to verify online or at a participating U.S. post office. Get step-by-step instructions

input: What steps do I need to take to update my address for all my VA benefits and services?
expected_output:
To update your address for most VA benefits and services, you can follow these steps:

1. **Update Your VA.gov Profile:** Log in to your VA.gov account and change your address in your profile. This update will apply to the following services:
   - VA health care (including prescriptions and appointment reminders)
   - Disability compensation
   - Pension benefits
   - Claims and appeals
   - Veteran Readiness and Employment (VR&E)

2. **Contact Individual Departments for Specific Benefits:** Some VA services require you to notify them directly. Here are the contact numbers for those specific benefits:
   - **Education Benefits:** Call 888-442-4551 (TTY: 711), Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. ET.
   - **Home Loan Benefits:** Call 877-827-3702, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. ET.
   - **CHAMPVA:** Call 800-733-8387, Monday through Friday, 8:05 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. ET, or send a signed request to CHAMPVA PO Box 500, Spring City, PA 19475.
   - **Foreign Medical Program:** Call 877-345-8179, Monday through Friday, 8:05 a.m. to 6:45 p.m. ET, or send a signed request to VHA Office of Community Care Foreign Medical Program (FMP) PO Box 469061, Denver, CO 80246-9061.
   - **Life Insurance Benefits:** Update your Servicemembers’ Group Life Insurance (SGLI) or Family SGLI via milConnect. For Veterans’ Group Life Insurance (VGLI), visit the Prudential website or send a request to OSGLI PO Box 41618, Philadelphia, PA 19176-9913.

If you need specific instructions or have further questions on changing your address for any other VA services, feel free to ask!
context:
URL: https://www.va.gov/resources/change-your-address-on-file-with-va
Title: Change Your Address On File With VA | Veterans Affairs
Content:
Search resources and support Resources and Support All VA.gov Enter a keyword, phrase, or question Change your address on file with VA You can change your address in your VA.gov profile for certain VA benefits and services. But some departments keep your address in their own separate records, so you’ll need to contact them directly. Read on to learn about how to change your address on file with VA. Change your address online in your VA.gov profile When you change your address and other contact information online in your VA.gov profile, it updates across these VA benefits and services: VA health care (including prescriptions, appointment reminders, lab and test results, and communications from your VA medical center) Disability compensation Pension benefits Claims and appeals Veteran Readiness and Employment (VR&E) Find out how to change your address in your VA.gov profile Change your address by contacting the department directly Some of our departments keep your contact information in their own separate records. If you use any of the VA benefits or services listed here, you’ll need to contact the department that handles those benefits directly to change your information. Education benefits Call us at 888-442-4551 ( TTY: 711 ). We’re here Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. ET. Find out how to update your contact information for verifying enrollment Home loan benefits Call us at 877-827-3702 . We’re here Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. ET. We can connect you to the nearest VA regional office with loan guaranty staff to update your information. CHAMPVA Call our customer call center at 800-733-8387 . We’re here Monday through Friday, 8:05 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. ET. Please have your last address available. Our customer service representatives will need to verify this before updating your file. Or send a signed and dated address change request to us at: CHAMPVA PO Box 500 Spring City, PA 19475 The Foreign Medical Program Call our Foreign Medical Program office at 877-345-8179 . We’re here Monday through Friday, 8:05 a.m. to 6:45 p.m. ET Or send a signed and dated address change request to us at: VHA Office of Community Care Foreign Medical Program (FMP) PO Box 469061 Denver, CO 80246-9061 Life insurance benefits Servicemembers’ Group Life Insurance (SGLI) or Family SGLI (FSGLI) You can update your information online through milConnect. Go to milConnect to update your SGLI or FSGLI information Veterans’ Group Life Insurance (VGLI) You can update your information online through the Prudential website or by sending a letter to Prudential. Go to the Prudential website to update your VGLI information Or send a signed and dated address change request to Prudential at: OSGLI PO Box 41618 Philadelphia, PA 19176-9913 Servicemembers’ Group Life Insurance Traumatic Injury Protection (TSGLI) You can find the contact information for your uniformed service on the first page of the Application for TSGLI Benefits (SGLV 8600). Get SGLV 8600 to download Other VA life insurance programs If you have life insurance through any of these VA programs, you can call us or send us a letter to update your information: Veterans Affairs Life Insurance (VALife) Veterans’ Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) Service-Disabled Veterans Life Insurance (S-DVI) United States Government Life Insurance (USGLI) National Service Life Insurance (NSLI) Veterans’ Special Life Insurance (VSLI) Veterans’ Reopened Insurance Call our VA Insurance Center (VAIC) at 800-669-8477 . Call for current hours. Or send a signed and dated address change request to us at: Department of Veterans Affairs Regional Office and Insurance Center PO Box 7208 Philadelphia, PA 19101 Tags All Veterans Good Bad Want to share more feedback? We'll use it to keep improving VA.gov for all Veterans and their families. Complete our 3-question survey. Related information VA benefits Health care Apply for VA health care, find out how to access services, and manage your health and benefits online. Need more help? MyVA411 main information line: 800-698-2411 Last updated: May 21, 2025 Feedback
